quoteFirst: The day was spent in sleeping and eating, and at
quoteLast: we started with the intention of marching all night. But by ten everybody was tired and sleepy. Even Mohammed was riding his camel.
title: The lost oases

quoteFirst: Chester Young had complained of feeling unwell and had announced that he was going over to the drug store for some medicine. That had been, as near as Walter could recall, about
quoteLast: . It might have been a little before that. Walter evidently had no suspicions and Joe didn’t enlighten him.
title: First Base Faulkner
author: Mathewson, Christy, 1880-1925; Relyea, C. M. (Charles M.), 1863-1932 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: “Well, I saw a fellow riding along Bennett Street yesterday about a
quoteLast: on a wheel that looked a lot like Warren’s. I thought, of course, it was his, because his is the only brand-new one I’ve seen in town, but I guess maybe it wasn’t.”
title: Follow the Ball
author: Barbour, Ralph Henry, 1870-1944

quoteFirst: The procession of patients had been long, and more than once in the tiny interval between the exit of one and the entry of another, Dr. Levillier had peeped at his watch. His last appointment was at
quoteLast: , then he would be free, and he said to himself that he would take a cab and drive down to Victoria Street. Valentine was often at home about six. The doctor put aside the little devil of pride that whispered, "You have been badly treated," and resolved to make the advance to this friend, who seemed to have forgotten him.
title: Flames
author: Hichens, Robert, 1864-1950

quoteLast: . I went to his house and the landlady said he’d taken his baggage and gone. I――I want to see him and ask him something.

quoteLast: . Tanner was in desperation. And then to his relief his eye fell on a policeman. It was the work of a moment to call him over, explain the situation, and get him up beside the driver.
title: The Ponson case

quoteFirst: The pleasant personal feeling is with you even after you have left the shelter of the White House roof. It is showering gently and a man under a tree is murmuring something about Secretary Bryan seeing visitors at
quoteLast: but neither makes impress upon you. You are merely thinking how much easier it is to come to see the President of the greatest republic in the world than many a lesser man within it--railroad heads, bankers, even petty politicians.
title: The Personality of American Cities
author: Hungerford, Edward, 1875-1948

quoteFirst: The corps commanders, however, reported that it was so dark that the men could not see to move, and it would be impossible to make the assault then. But we kept up a continuous artillery fire upon the enemy around the whole line including that north of the James River, until it was light enough to move, which was about
